data.text: Listen to Music while Bike Touring / Camping

ðŸŽµ Music while touring ðŸŽµ What are people's preferences with music while they ride/camp? In the past I've used a small Bluetooth speaker in my frame bag, but I'm now considering saving some space/weight/battery power and just getting some wired earphones (one at a time on a busy road!). Would like to hear how you all groove n move.
BT speaker In Cambodia I like to hear whatâ€™s coming..

data.text: true... I've always been keen on the idea of getting a handlebar holder for the speaker 3D printed somewhere

data.text: thatâ€™s a good idea
data.author: Derrick Murray

data.text: I always tour with headphones, listening to music at low volume. I turn it off in towns, or when road conditions require. I often carry a small Bluetooth speaker for listening off bike
data.author: Larry Sanders

data.text: I just put the speaker in my handlebar bag
data.author: Parsa Jazni

data.text: if you got bone conduction earphones, you could probably use both ears at once since the earphone doesn't block the auditory canal ?
data.author: Paul Josephsson

data.text: although a quick search suggests that they're all wireless ðŸ˜•
data.author: Paul Josephsson

data.text: As is a Bluetooth speaker ðŸ¤¨ Whatâ€™s the difference? Both use Bluetooth
data.author: Liz Zylinski

data.text: bone conduction headphones mean that you hear the music, but other people aren't forced to. my point was that I'd looked to see what was available and doesn't seem to be any wired bone conduction headphones, and OP did stipulate wired (presumably to save battery life)
data.author: Paul Josephsson

data.text: never heard of bone conduction headphones until now! And yes, well deduced for battery life ðŸ˜‰
data.author: Adam Jackson

data.text: Thanks for mansplaining bone conduction headphones. Eight hour plus battery life should be enough for most headphone users? Thatâ€™s what I get from mine.
data.author: Liz Zylinski

data.text: used them before the sweat killed them, they were pretty darned good up until then
data.author: Derrick Murray

data.text: Zealot S1 BT speaker mounted on the handlebars.
data.author: Brent Irvine

data.text: Sing
data.author: Todd Ostler

data.text: I just play my Spotify tunes on my iPhone at a fairly low level without earphones or bluetooth speaker. The iPhone is in my handlebar bag and I can hear it well enough without it interfering with my attention to traffic sounds. Sound quality is not great from the iPhone, but as I said, it's good enough!
data.author: Hope W. Martin

data.text: Bone conduction headphones
data.author: Timothy Dale

data.text: I sing like I'm in the shower...loud and proud.
data.author: Theresa McGann

data.text: Wireless is fine for day rides but when touring, to many gadgets that need chargingâ€¦ phone, lights, headphones, speakers, gps, cameras (s), drone, power banks to charge it allâ€¦ Yes there are dynamo hubs that can charge but they are very expensive. In the days gone by we had 1 camera with a battery that lasted for a year or more and a paper map (no battery required).
data.author: Morrie Portnoff

data.text: JBL Clip. The clip is held together with duct tape at this point, but the speaker still sounds great and is waterproof too. I ride with my partner a lot, so it's nice that we can both listen.
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: I have the same.. With duct tape
data.author: Derrick Murray

data.text: i use the same jbl clip for my rides i love it.
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text: love my JBL clip! Lightweight, surprisingly strong and goes all day
data.author: Jane Severn

data.text: Do they take long to recharge? My only concern would be it taking up too much of my battery pack's charge!
data.author: Adam Jackson

data.text: Not really, but we don't use our battery packs to charge it. We wait until we get somewhere with outlets. We only use our battery packs for the essentials - phone and GPS, generally.
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: Birds, bugs and the breeze is how I groove when I move.
data.author: David Ziccardi

data.text: shokz bone conduction headphones. can hear traffic.
data.author: Ginnis McGinnis

data.text: None
data.author: Jeff Neumann

data.text: 100 miles a day listening to just the nature and traffic sounds around me will get boring to me after a few days. i like to mix it up, riding in silence, riding with rush hour traffic noises, riding while on the phone with friends or family, listening to podcast, or music. depends on my mood. sometimes i sing at the top of my lungs as i pass by onlookers who think i am crazy . i have a jbl clip speaker right on my cockpit , one of the best investments i made for my setup.
data.author: Christian Ramos

data.text:
I got Shokz headphones and am very impressed. I used to have a small weatherproof speaker that I attached to the bike, but these open air headphones are way better. Long battery life, decent sound, ultra light, weatherproof, and you can still hear everything around you. https://shokz.com/
Shokz Official | The Professional Bone Conduction Headphones Pioneer
shokz.com
data.author: Dave Mull

data.text: Depends where I'm riding ... busy roads I use bone conducting ... long country routes either wired earbuds or a par of Sennheiser closed back headphones (mainly depending on the weather as the Sennheisers have velvet pads ) .... really quiet offroad trails blutooth speaker
data.author: Stuart Mather

data.text: Bluetooth speaker all the way. Wearing headphones makes me feel paranoid about being hit. I carry a JBL flip and keep it in my extra water bottle cage.
data.author: Gerald Raton

data.text: Bluetooth speaker for me. I get maybe 20 or more hours of use on one charge, it is cheap, waterproof and a good base response, although only mono. I strap it to my bars. I find it great for pumping up hills. Choice of music varies, but mainly dance music, for the rhythm, or rock music. When at camp, I may even listen to classical, or chillout music. At camp I use Bluetooth in-ear phones. I can enjoy the stereo and not disturb others, or if being stealthy no give away the fact that I am there. As for headphones on the bike, the only type I would consider (personal choice) are the bone induction headphones, I listened to a pair my buddy has, they were awesome, much better than I imagined. Your ears are not covered, and you enjoy full stereo. I have tried wired phones and earbuds and always seem to catch the wire and pull them out of my ears or off my head, which could prove to be a dangerous distraction.
data.author: Mark Perry

data.text:
I use something like these. I run the cord inside my shirt and out the bottom to my jersey pocket. low tech, great sound. https://www.bestbuy.com/site/sony-wired-extra-bass-in-ear-headphones-black/6476190.p?skuId=6476190&ref=212&loc=1&extStoreId=863&ref=212&loc=1&gclid=CjwKCAjwiuuRBhBvEiwAFXKaNBnTArTd4BsJQVfO0vQ_8p5v-8hw96BzL1Wl4xb0IB4bPx-qY4DVyRoCa5sQAvD_BwE&gclsrc=aw.ds
Best Buy International: Select your Country - Best Buy
bestbuy.com
data.author: David Baker-Yuill

data.text: I use wired headphones with a small ipod clipped to my handlebarbag. I listen to electronic music like this and it sure helps motivate me! https://soundcloud.app.goo.gl/DvidF
data.author: Hudson Doyle

data.text: Aftershocks Aeropex.
data.author: Pete Dougherty

data.text:
Monster Boomerang. Waterproof... Even managed the kind of downpour only the tropics can provide, whilst touring the east coast of Malaysia. Relatively light and comfortable. Nothing in ear, so can hear the road just fine, sound quality is very good, battery life is epic (whole day riding no problem) and recharge time very, very short (shorter than the 1.5hrs stated in my experience - more like 40mins). If mine failed for any reason I would buy another one without hesitation. https://www.google.com/url?sa=t&source=web&rct=j&url=https://monsterstore.com/products/monster-boomerang-neckband-bluetooth-speaker-lightweight-wireless-wearable-speaker-with-12h-playtime-true-3d-stereo-sound-portable-and-ipx7-waterproof-ideal-for-home-outdoors&ved=2ahUKEwiCmN-9s9z2AhUF3jgGHQVIBLsQFnoECAkQAQ&usg=AOvVaw2AnxN5fhJ1Il9t2MBXAebQ
Monster Boomerang Wearable Bluetooth Speaker
monsterstore.com
data.author: David Hughes

data.text: I use Anker earbuds similar to these, they last about 12-17 hours I think. I just plug in one ear and tuck the rest away in my jersey (don't feel it, but if the earbud falls out you don't lose it). And in some situations it's convenient to adjust volume directly on the earbud wire (or pause music/skip songs etc) or just take it out if you want to hear around you. Having said that, I'm considering getting a small speaker for when I cycle through bear country I want full awareness of what is around me and something to indicate a human approaching to bears :)
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text:
https://www.anker.com/products/variant/soundbuds-flow/A3234011
SoundBuds Flow
anker.com
data.author: Ahmd Lim

data.text: As mentioned above, bone conduction headphones would be a safest option as you can hear what's around you. Also others don't need to hear your music/noise (if anyone around)
data.author: Edmundas Maiga

data.text: I usually tune into local radio. Nice insight into the area, sometimes get better tips on weather, road closures and stuff, and even events or festivals that might be happening and worth checking out.
data.author: Jason Roussel

data.text: nice I love this one!
data.author: Adam Jackson

data.text:
Is anyone using a smart helmet to listen to music? Like the Sena R1 for example?https://www.sena.com/us-en/product/r1
R1 - Smart Road Cycling Helmet | Sena
sena.com
data.author: Hope W. Martin

data.text: The distraction that listening to music, podcasts, or other electronics is very high. I prefer to devote my attention to the land I am passing through. Cyclists are in high enough danger without adding to it by being distracted. It is not the hearing, but the concentration that we lose. If music motivates you then it is focusing your concentration away from driving your bicycle.
data.author: Bill Heimann

data.text: I have a tiny blue tooth speaker that I use sparingly (on climbs or in the dulldrums) and would not wear headphones while cycling (or anywhere I need to hear stuff like walking alone). Brands I've used: Boombotix, marsboy and jbl.
data.author: Lindsey Hamma

data.text: Bone conducting earphones. You can hear traffic etc, but not blast your music on everyone else. Mine are cheapo Â£18 Lenovo ones, but do the job fine.
data.author: Steve Holland

data.text: just ride with some mates ðŸ˜‰ðŸš´

data.text: JBL Flip 5, waterproof (to a point), loud as hell, if you want, great bass response.
data.author: Tim Clarke

data.text: Approx 50% of the time Iâ€™m listening to whatâ€™s going on around me and the other half music on a pair of Bluetooth Sony earbuds.

data.text: Podcasts

data.text: Mifo 07â€™s. IMHO, really good sound and great battery life!

data.text: Aftershokz.
data.author: Leyne Milstein

data.text: ipod touch 128GB holds most of my music collection and good to run all day thru whatever corded headphones I have at the time.
data.author: Michael Finn

data.text: I use earphones when I am camping. I do not want to disturb other campers. Sometimes, I listen to audio books when I am riding. The audio books are on my phone, I do not use earphones when I am listening to audio books and riding; I keep the volume low.
data.author: Jean Phillips

data.text: Aftershockz, skull Candy makes a set of ambient headphones, Sony makes an excellent pair of bt headphones but they are costly. We have 2 pairs of aftershocks. A wired and a wireless one. Both need to be charged. On a different vibe. My Razer Kraken gaming headphones are open backed. So on low volume you would be able to hear around you. But they are bulky and would lose the ability to wear a helmet.
data.author: Jordan Nickel
